Vegetarian Stir-Fry

Jump to Recipe

If you're searching for a quick, delicious, and healthy meal, look no further than this vibrant Vegetarian Stir-Fry recipe! Packed with colorful vegetables like bell peppers, broccoli, and snap peas, this dish is not only visually appealing but also brimming with nutrients. Perfect for busy weeknights, this stir-fry comes together in just under 15 minutes, making it an ideal option for anyone looking to whip up a wholesome dinner without spending hours in the kitchen. With a savory soy sauce glaze and a hint of garlic, every bite bursts with flavor, ensuring that even the pickiest eaters will be asking for seconds. Whether you’re a devoted vegetarian or simply trying to incorporate more plant-based meals into your diet, this Vegetarian Stir-Fry is a satisfying choice that can easily be customized with your favorite vegetables or proteins. Let’s get cooking!

Ingredients

bell peppers

When choosing bell peppers, opt for firm ones with vibrant color. Red bell peppers are sweeter, while green ones are slightly bitter. If you need a substitute, you can use other sweet peppers or even zucchini for a different texture.

broccoli florets

Look for bright green, firm florets. To enhance the flavor, you can blanch the broccoli quickly in boiling water before adding it to the stir-fry. If you don't have broccoli, cauliflower or green beans can be good alternatives.

carrot

Choose firm, vibrant carrots. For even cooking, slice them thinly or julienne them. If you have baby carrots, they can be used whole or halved. If you want a sweet flavor, consider adding shredded carrots.

snap peas

Select crisp, bright green snap peas. They should snap easily when bent. If unavailable, you can substitute with sugar snap peas or even thinly sliced green beans.

soy sauce

Use low-sodium soy sauce for a healthier option, or tamari for a gluten-free alternative. For a different flavor profile, consider using coconut aminos or liquid aminos.

garlic

Fresh garlic is best; use a garlic press for even mincing. If you don't have fresh garlic, garlic powder can be used (1/8 teaspoon per clove). Roasting the garlic before adding it can also enhance its sweetness.

olive oil

Extra virgin olive oil adds flavor, but you can substitute with sesame oil for a more traditional stir-fry taste, or canola oil for a neutral flavor. Make sure the oil is hot before adding vegetables to achieve that nice sear.

sesame seeds (optional)

Toasting sesame seeds before sprinkling them on will enhance their nutty flavor. If you don’t have sesame seeds, crushed peanuts or sunflower seeds can provide a nice crunch.

green onions (for garnish)

Choose firm, green onions with no wilting. Both the white and green parts are edible and flavorful. If you don't have green onions, chives or shallots can be used as substitutes.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Heat the Oil

    Start by heating 2 tablespoons of olive oil in a large skillet or wok over medium-high heat. This oil will help to cook the vegetables evenly and add flavor.

  • Step 2: Sauté Garlic

    Once the oil is hot, add 2 cloves of minced garlic to the skillet. Sauté for about 30 seconds until fragrant. Be careful not to burn the garlic as it can become bitter.

  • Step 3: Add Vegetables

    Next, add 1 sliced carrot, 2 bell peppers (1 red and 1 green) cut into strips, and 1 cup of broccoli florets. Stir-fry these vegetables for about 5 minutes until they start to soften.

  • Step 4: Introduce Snap Peas

    Now, add 1 cup of snap peas to the skillet. Continue to stir-fry for another 3-4 minutes. The snap peas should remain crisp, so avoid overcooking them.

  • Step 5: Add Soy Sauce

    Pour in 2 tablespoons of soy sauce and mix well to coat the vegetables evenly. Allow the mixture to cook for an additional 2 minutes to combine the flavors.

  • Step 6: Garnish and Serve

    Remove the stir-fry from heat. Sprinkle with 1 tablespoon of sesame seeds (if using) and 2 sliced green onions before serving. This adds a nice crunch and freshness to the dish.

Frequently Asked Questions

What are the best ways to prepare vegetables for stir-frying?

Start by washing all your vegetables under cold water. For bell peppers, slice them into thin strips; for broccoli, cut florets into bite-sized pieces; slice the carrot into thin rounds or matchsticks; and trim the ends of the snap peas. Cutting everything uniformly helps them cook evenly.

How do I know when my vegetables are done cooking?

Vegetables should be vibrant in color and tender-crisp. You want them to have some bite, so they should not be mushy. Typically, stir-frying for 5-7 minutes should suffice, but keep an eye on the texture.

Is it safe to use a high cooking temperature?

Yes, using medium-high heat is essential for stir-frying. It allows the vegetables to cook quickly while retaining their color and texture. Just be sure to stir continuously to prevent burning.

What can I substitute for soy sauce if I want a gluten-free option?

You can use tamari, which is a gluten-free soy sauce alternative. Alternatively, coconut aminos can work well and offer a slightly sweeter flavor.

How can I make my stir-fry more flavorful?

In addition to soy sauce, consider adding ginger, chili flakes, or a splash of rice vinegar for extra depth. Experimenting with fresh herbs or spices can also elevate the dish.

Can I add protein to my vegetarian stir-fry?

Absolutely! You can add tofu, tempeh, or even chickpeas to increase the protein content. If using tofu, make sure to press it to remove excess moisture and cut it into cubes before cooking.

What equipment do I need for stir-frying?

A large skillet or wok is ideal for stir-frying. Ensure it has a wide surface area to allow for even cooking. A wooden spoon or spatula for stirring is also helpful.

How do I safely handle hot oil?

Always heat oil gradually and avoid splashing. Use a splatter guard if you have one, and keep a safe distance from the pan. If you see smoke, reduce the heat immediately.

What can I serve with my stir-fry?

Stir-fry pairs well with rice, quinoa, or noodles. You can also serve it on its own as a light meal or alongside a fresh salad.

Can I store leftovers and how should I do it?

Yes! Store leftovers in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 3 days. Reheat in a pan over medium heat or in the microwave until warmed through.

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

This Vegetarian Stir-Fry is naturally vegan and gluten-free if you use gluten-free soy sauce or tamari. For those following a low-carb diet, you can substitute the rice with cauliflower rice. To enhance the nutritional value, feel free to add other vegetables such as zucchini or mushrooms, and for added flavor, consider a splash of sesame oil before serving.

Pairings

For a well-rounded meal, serve the Vegetarian Stir-Fry alongside steamed jasmine rice or quinoa to absorb the savory soy sauce. If you're looking for protein, consider adding tofu or tempeh, marinated and pan-fried until golden. Pair with a crisp white wine like Sauvignon Blanc or a refreshing iced green tea to complement the dish's flavors.

Serving Suggestions

Serve the stir-fry hot directly from the skillet onto plates, allowing the vibrant colors of the vegetables to shine. Garnish generously with sliced green onions and a sprinkle of sesame seeds for added texture and flavor. For a casual dining experience, serve it in bowls, allowing for easy mixing with rice or quinoa. Consider adding lime wedges on the side for a zesty finish that brightens the dish.

#

Vegetarian Stir-Fry

25 min
$10
250 kcal
Difficulty: 20%
Servings: 2

Allergens:

Soy

Dietary Tags:

VegetarianVeganGluten-Free

Cuisine:

AsianFusion

Course:

MainSide

Tags:

QuickHealthyColorfulEasy

Description

A colorful and healthy mix of vegetables stir-fried to perfection with a light soy sauce glaze.

Ingredients

  • bell peppers: 2 (red and green)
  • broccoli florets: 1 cup
  • carrot: 1 (sliced)
  • snap peas: 1 cup
  • soy sauce: 2 tablespoons
  • garlic: 2 cloves (minced)
  • olive oil: 2 tablespoons
  • sesame seeds (optional): 1 tablespoon
  • green onions (for garnish): 2 (sliced)

Date Created:

11/17/2024
